awd_titl_txt: Investigation of the Effect of Strong Currents on Superconducting Properties and Surface Resistance of High Performance Materials for Accelerator Cavities
awd_abstract_narration:
The primary aim of this project is to improve the performance of particle accelerators, opening new possibilities for high-energy experiments on the fundamental nature of matter.  Currently, particle accelerators rely on superconducting radio frequency (SRF) resonator cavities to accelerate and control beams of charged particles in high energy collision experiments (such as at the Large Hadron Collider at CERN) or in x-ray lasers (such as at the Coherent Light Source at SLAC). Increasing the accelerating fields and reducing power consumption of SRF cavities is essential for the development of the next generation of accelerators. Two objectives will be pursued in this work. First is the understanding of fundamental physical and materials science mechanisms behind optimization of the state of the art superconducting cavities made with alloys of Niobium (Nb). The second effort is focused on new accelerating structures and superconducting materials which could significantly improve the performance of the superconducting cavities as compared to Nb. This work will suggest efficient ways of improving the performance of SRF accelerator cavities and will engage undergraduate and graduate students in this area of great interest to physics and future applications by providing them with training in key technological areas.

The main goal of this project is to investigate the local quasiparticle density of states of SRF materials and to correlate it with different materials treatments (such as low-temperature baking and nitrogen infusion) and surface resistance measurements. The quasiparticle density of states is a key characteristic determining the power loss and the high-field performance of SRF cavities. The synergy of new experimental techniques (low temperature scanning tunneling microscopy and spectroscopy) and theory will allow the group to address the underlying physics and materials science mechanisms which are instrumental for achieving higher accelerating gradients and lower power losses in SRF cavities.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TEMPLE UNIVERSITY-OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the understanding of the fundamental physical and materials science mechanisms behind the optimization of the state-of-the-art Niobium cavities. Current outstanding issues limiting the performance of radio-frequency (RF) Nb cavities were addressed both experimentally and theoretically with a synergistic approach that correlates the surface electronic properties, the structural and chemical characterization with the RF response of Niobium and Nitrogen-doped Niobium cavities. Theoretical modeling of the complex Niobium surface helped disentangle different contributions.

 This synergistic approach allowed to highlight the mechanism behind the striking improvement resulting from the nitrogen doping of the state-of-the-art Nb resonators. Low temperature scanning tunneling microscopy and spectroscopy and x-ray photoemission spectroscopy show that the N-doping causes profound changes to the Nb oxide surface. In particular, it reduces the thickness of metallic suboxides and changes the interface between the bulk Niobium and the surface oxide, while ameliorating lateral inhomogeneities of the superconducting gap. This work shows how superconducting properties can be tuned by impurities to reduce RF losses. (E. Lechner et al. Physical Review Applied 13, 044044 (2020))

 Furthermore, in Nitrogen-doped Niobium RF cavities, combined surface and bulk techniques were used to characterize the surface oxide layer, the superconducting properties and the cavity performance.  Thermometry mapping was used to locate quench locations of the cavities (hot spots). Quenched (hot-spots) and non-quenched (cold-spots) locations were compared. Our study shows that the weakly degraded superconducting properties at hot-spot locations are not the main source of RF losses, rather they may facilitate vortex nucleation or trapping and account for the RF losses at these cavities’ locations. (E. Lechner et al. Front. Electron. Mater. 3, 1235918 (2023))

 

 


Last Modified: 11/20/2023
Modified by: Maria Iavarone

Images (1 of )
  • Line of 50 tunneling spectra acquired across a defective region (hot spot location) showing local changes in the quasiparticle density of states and the presence of localized states in the gap.

  • (a) Scanning Tunneling Spectroscopy map of trapped Abrikosov vortices at a hot spot location. The image is a conductance map acquired at E=EF at T=1.5 K after removing a field of H=0.15 T applied perpendicular to the surface.

por.por_txt_cntn:
This project focused on the understanding of the fundamental physical and materials science mechanisms behind the optimization of the state-of-the-art Niobium cavities. Current outstanding issues limiting the performance of radio-frequency (RF) Nb cavities were addressed both experimentally and theoretically with a synergistic approach that correlates the surface electronic properties, the structural and chemical characterization with the RF response of Niobium and Nitrogen-doped Niobium cavities. Theoretical modeling of the complex Niobium surface helped disentangle different contributions.


This synergistic approach allowed to highlight the mechanism behind the striking improvement resulting from the nitrogen doping of the state-of-the-art Nb resonators. Low temperature scanning tunneling microscopy and spectroscopy and x-ray photoemission spectroscopy show that the N-doping causes profound changes to the Nb oxide surface. In particular, it reduces the thickness of metallic suboxides and changes the interface between the bulk Niobium and the surface oxide, while ameliorating lateral inhomogeneities of the superconducting gap. This work shows how superconducting properties can be tuned by impurities to reduce RF losses. (E. Lechner et al. Physical Review Applied 13, 044044 (2020))


Furthermore, in Nitrogen-doped Niobium RF cavities, combined surface and bulk techniques were used to characterize the surface oxide layer, the superconducting properties and the cavity performance. Thermometry mapping was used to locate quench locations of the cavities (hot spots). Quenched (hot-spots) and non-quenched (cold-spots) locations were compared. Our study shows that the weakly degraded superconducting properties at hot-spot locations are not the main source of RF losses, rather they may facilitate vortex nucleation or trapping and account for the RF losses at these cavities locations. (E. Lechner et al. Front. Electron. Mater. 3, 1235918 (2023))
